{{infobox football tournament season | title = Norwegian Football Cup | year = 1994 | country = {{NOR}} | num_teams = | defending champions = [[FK Bodø/Glimt|Bodø/Glimt]] | champions = [[Molde FK|Molde]] (1st title) | runner-up = [[FC Lyn Oslo|Lyn]] | matches = | goals = | champ_match_score = 3–2 | top goal scorer = | player = | prevseason = [[1993 Norwegian Football Cup|1993]] | nextseason = [[1995 Norwegian Football Cup|1995]] }} The '''1994 [[Norwegian Football Cup]]''' was the 89th edition of the [[Norway|Norwegian]] Football Cup. The 1994 Norwegian Football Cup 1994 was won by [[Molde FK|Molde]] after they defeated [[FC Lyn Oslo|Lyn]] in the cup final with the score 3–2. Both teams played in the [[1. divisjon]] (Level 2) at the time. ==Final== {{main|1994 Norwegian Football Cup Final}} {{footballbox |date =23 October 1994 |time = |team1 = [[Molde FK|Molde]] |score =3–2 (2–1) |report = |team2 =[[FC Lyn Oslo|Lyn]] |goals1 =[[Tarje Nordstrand Jacobsen]] {{goal|12}}
[[Ole Bjørn Sundgot]] {{goal|42}}
[[Arild Stavrum]] {{goal|48}} |goals2 =[[Jo Tessem]] {{goal|9}}
[[Jan Derek Sørensen]] {{goal|59}} |stadium =[[Ullevaal Stadion]] |attendance =24 524 |referee =[[Terje Singsaas]] ([[Rosenborg BK|Rosenborg]]) |penalties1 = |penaltyscore = |penalties2 = }} '''Molde's winning team''': [[Morten Bakke]], [[Trond Strande]], [[Sindre Rekdal]], [[José María Glaria Azivanda|Flaco]], [[Knut Anders Fostervold]], [[Ulrich Møller]], [[Tarje Nordstrand Jacobsen]], ([[André Nevstad]] 86), [[Kjetil Rekdal]], [[Daniel Berg Hestad]], ([[Tor Gunnar Johnsen]] 80), [[Ole Bjørn Sundgot]], [[Arild Stavrum]], [[Petter Rudi]], [[Berdon Sønderland]] and [[Jan Berg (footballer born 1965)|Jan Berg]]. '''Lyn's team''': [[Ståle Oldeide]], [[Thomas Østvold]], ([[Tom Buer]] 90), [[Thomas Wæhler]], [[Anders Eriksson (footballer)|Anders Eriksson]], [[Sigbjørn Kolnes]], [[Axel Kolle]], [[Stein Amundsen]], [[Sture Fladmark]], [[Jan Derek Sørensen]], [[Jo Tessem]], [[Tommy Bergersen]] and ([[Anders Rønnevig]] 75). ==References== *[http://www.rsssf.no/1994/fcup http://www.rsssf.no] {{Norwegian Football Cup}} {{1994 in Norwegian football}} {{1993–94 in European football (UEFA)}} {{1994–95 in European football (UEFA)}} [[Category:Norwegian Football Cup seasons]] [[Category:1994 domestic association football cups|Norway]] [[Category:1994 in Norwegian football|Football Cup]] {{Norway-footy-competition-stub}}

revision.text:
{{For|other clubs with the same name|AS Douanes (disambiguation){{!}}AS Douanes}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = AS Douanes| image = [[Image:AS Douanes (Niamey).jpg|130px]]| fullname = Association Sportive des Douanes de Niamey| nickname = | founded = | ground = [[Général Seyni Kountché Stadion]]
[[Niamey]], [[Niger]]| capacity = 30,000| chairman = | manager = | league = [[Niger Premier League]] | season = 2011/12 | position = 3rd| pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=|pattern_ra1=| leftarm1=0000FF|body1=0000FF|rightarm1=0000FF|shorts1=0000FF|socks1=FFFFFF| [http://addessahmed.blogspot.com/2007/10/togo-drapeau-et-hymne-mdias-msn-encarta.html 2005 Image of kit from] }} '''AS Douanes''' (fr:''Association Sportive des Douanes de Niamey'' – en:''Niamey Customs enforcement Sports Association'') is a [[Niger]]ien [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Niamey]] and sponsored by the government taxation police. Prior to the 2005–6 season they played in the city of [[Tillabéry]],{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesn/niger04.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-10-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081005143029/http://www.rsssf.com/tablesn/niger04.html |archivedate=2008-10-05 |df= }} and have competed in the top national league since the 2004 season, when they were promoted from the regional division 2.{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesn/niger03.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-10-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081008014806/http://www.rsssf.com/tablesn/niger03.html |archivedate=2008-10-08 |df= }} AS Douanes has won Nigerien league once but have never won cup championship.http://www.rsssf.com/tablesn/nigerchamp.html
{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081024020051/http://www.rsssf.com/tablesn/nigerchamp.html |date=October 24, 2008 }} http://www.rsssf.com/tablesn/nigercuphist.html ==2008 season== AS Douanes finished in third place in Group A of the first round of the 2008 [[Niger Premier League]]. They failed to qualify for the championship round, but easily avoided the elimination playoff, meaning they will return for the 2009 season. ==Achievements== *'''[[Niger Premier League]]: 2''' ::2013, 2015 *'''[[Niger Cup]]: 1''' ::2016 ==Performance in CAF competitions== *'''[[CAF Champions League]]: 1 appearances''' ::2014 – Preliminary round *'''[[CAF Confederation Cup]]: 0 appearances''' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.rsssf.com/tablesn/niger08.html Rec Sports Soccer Foundation: Niger 2008: Championnat national de première division]. {{Football in Niger}} {{Niger Premier League}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Douanes As}} [[Category:Football clubs in Niger]] [[Category:Niger Premier League clubs]] [[Category:Sport in Niamey]] {{Niger-footyclub-stub}}

revision.text:
{{use dmy dates|date=March 2012}}{{Infobox stadium | name = Borough Park | nickname = | image = Workington Association Football Club Ground - geograph.org.uk - 3242006.jpg | image_size = 270px | caption = Borough Park, seen from the new Northside Bridge | fullname = | location = [[Workington]], [[England]] | coordinates = {{Coord|54|38|55.37|N|3|33|03.78|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1937 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | surface = Grass | cost = | architect = | capacity = 3,101 (500 seated) | record_attendance = 21,000 | dimensions = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Workington A.F.C.]]
[[Workington Town]] (1944–1956) }} '''Borough Park''' is a [[association football|football]] stadium in [[Workington]], [[England]]. The home ground of [[Workington A.F.C.]], it has a capacity of 3,101, of which 500 is seated. ==History== Borough Park was built with the assistance of the local council, and opened in 1937, with Workington moving from their previous [[Lonsdale Park]] ground, which was next to Borough Park. The ground initially consisted of a 1,000-seat main stand on the western touchline, and banking around the remainder of the pitch, but by 1951 the embankments had been converted to terracing, and two more stands erected in the north-west and south-west corners of the ground.Paul Smith & Shirley Smith (2005) ''The Ultimate Directory of English & Scottish Football League Grounds Second Edition 1888–2005'', Yore Publications, p26, {{ISBN|0954783042}} Workington were elected to [[the Football League]] in 1951, and the first League match at Borough Park saw them defeat [[Chesterfield F.C.|Chesterfield]] 3–1 in front of 11,000 spectators. The ground underwent further expansion during the 1950s as the main stand was extended and the terracing on the eastern side of the pitch was roofed in 1956. The record attendance of 21,000 was set on 4 January 1958 for an [[FA Cup]] match against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]. The League record attendance of 18,628 was set for a local derby against [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] on 26 December 1963. Workington were voted out of the League in 1977. The main stand was closed and the roof removed in 1988. Borough Park was also the home of the town's rugby league club [[Workington Town]] from when they formed after the [[Second World War]] in 1945 until they moved out in 1956 and into their own new ground nearby, [[Derwent Park]], where they remain today. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Workington A.F.C.]] [[Category:Football venues in England]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1937]] [[Category:Sports venues in Cumbria]] [[Category:Workington]] [[Category:English Football League venues]] {{England-sports-venue-stub}}

([[Los Ángeles, Chile]]; 17 November 2017) | Largest win = {{rl|Brazil}} 52-14 {{rl-rt|Colombia}}
([[Sao Paulo]], [[Brazil]]; 23 November 2018) | Largest loss = {{rl|Chile}} 54-8 {{rl-rt|Brazil}}
([[Los Ángeles, Chile]]; 17 November 2017) | World cup apps = 0 | World cup first = - | World cup best = - }} The '''Brazil national rugby league team''' represents [[Brazil]] in the sport of [[rugby league]]. The nation made its international debut at the inaugural Latin American Rugby League Championship held in [[Los Ángeles, Chile]] in November 2017, losing to the hosts in their first international match.[http://www.asiapacificrl.com/2017/11/16/teams-announced-latinoamericano-championship/ Teams announced for Latinoamericano Championship][http://www.asiapacificrl.com/2017/11/18/chile-face-argentina-latinoamericano-championship-final/ Chile to face Argentina in Latinoamericano Championship Final] The team are currently ranked 43rd, in the [[RLIF World Rankings]]. {{align|{{RLIF World Rankings|Brazil}}}} ==Current Squad== Squad selected for [[2018 South American Rugby League Cup]];https://www.asiapacificrl.com/2018/11/15/brazilian-teams-named-for-this-weekends-south-american-cups/ Brazilian teams named for South American Cups *Liniker Farias *Rogério Simões *Warlen Junior *Lucas Drudi *Douglas Parazi *Vinícius Hideo *Lucas Virias *Leandro Caetano *Jorge Cabral *Gudemberg Silva *Gabriel Eduardo *Bruno Gil *Zachary Grundy *Matheus Marinho *Danilo Vieira *Johnny Santos *Branco Meneses *Rafael Góes *Caio Ozzioli *Denes Cardozo *Arthur Isaac ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{International Rugby League}} {{National sports teams of Brazil}} [[Category:South American national rugby league teams]] [[Category:National sports teams of Brazil|R]] [[Category:National rugby league teams]] {{Brazil-sport-stub}}

at [[Sports Authority Field at Mile High (RTD)|Sports Authority Field at Mile High]] }} '''Broncos Stadium at Mile High''', previously known as '''Invesco Field at Mile High''' and '''Sports Authority Field at Mile High''', and commonly known as '''Mile High''', '''New Mile High''' or '''Mile High Stadium''', is an [[American football]] [[stadium]] in [[Denver|Denver, Colorado]], named ''Mile High'' due to the city's elevation of {{convert|5,280|ft}}.{{cite web|title=Stadium Elevation|url=http://www.sportsauthorityfieldatmilehigh.com/stadium-information/about-us/elevation-5280'|publisher=Sports Authority Field at Mile High|accessdate=January 9, 2018}} The primary tenant is the [[Denver Broncos]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL). It opened in 2001 to replace [[Mile High Stadium]] and was largely paid for by taxpayers.{{cite news|last=Murphy|first=Chuck|title=Tax off books, but not registers|url=http://www.denverpost.com/murphy/ci_19832010?IADID=Search-www.denverpost.com-www.denverpost.com|accessdate=31 January 2014|newspaper=Denver Post|date=2012-01-27}}{{cite web |url=http://www.mfsd.com/aboutus.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131018222123/http://mfsd.com/aboutus.html |archivedate=2013-10-18 |df= }} [[Invesco]] paid $120 million for the original naming rights, before [[Sports Authority]] secured them in 2011.{{cite news|last=Caldwell|first=Gray|title=A New Home|url=http://www.denverbroncos.com/news-and-blogs/article-1/A-New-Home/14d4a137-b809-4347-9eef-bfdf909b6106|publisher=Denver Broncos|date=August 16, 2011|accessdate=September 21, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170908035605/http://www.denverbroncos.com/news-and-blogs/article-1/A-New-Home/14d4a137-b809-4347-9eef-bfdf909b6106|archive-date=2017-09-08|dead-url=yes|df=}} Despite its sponsor's [[liquidation]] and closure in 2016, the Sports Authority name remained on the stadium for two years afterward because of regulatory hurdles. Nevertheless, the Broncos announced on January 2, 2018 that the stadium's exterior signage would be removed.{{cite news|last=DiLalla|first=Aric|title=Broncos to remove Sports Authority signage from stadium in coming weeks|url=http://www.denverbroncos.com/news-and-blogs/article-1/Broncos-to-remove-Sports-Authority-signage-from-stadium-in-coming-weeks/76176de0-7491-4219-91af-6748bb10aeb2|publisher=Denver Broncos|date=January 2, 2018|accessdate=January 9, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180109183301/http://www.denverbroncos.com/news-and-blogs/article-1/Broncos-to-remove-Sports-Authority-signage-from-stadium-in-coming-weeks/76176de0-7491-4219-91af-6748bb10aeb2|archive-date=2018-01-09|dead-url=yes|df=}} The stadium took on its current name on a temporary basis on June 20, 2018 after the city's stadium authority approved the change, hoping to resell naming rights.{{cite news|last=DiLalla|first=Aric|title='Broncos Stadium at Mile High' approved as temporary name for stadium|url=https://www.denverbroncos.com/news/broncos-stadium-at-mile-high-approved-as-temporary-name-for-stadium|publisher=Denver Broncos|date=June 20, 2018|accessdate=June 23, 2018}}{{cite news|last1=Renck|first1=Troy E.|last2=Miller|first2=Blair|title=Denver Broncos' stadium temporarily renamed 'Broncos Stadium at Mile High'|url=https://www.thedenverchannel.com/sports/broncos/denver-broncos-request-new-temporary-name-for-stadium|website=TheDenverChannel.com|date=June 20, 2018|accessdate=June 23, 2018}} ==Naming rights controversy== Many fans opposed a [[naming rights|corporate name]] and wished to retain the previous venue's name, "Mile High Stadium."{{cite web|url=http://www.poynter.org/dg.lts/id.5015/content.content_view.htm|title=A Mile High Controversy|first=Gregory E.|last=Favre|date=August 10, 2006|accessdate=September 25, 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061127001741/http://www.poynter.org/dg.lts/id.5015/content.content_view.htm|archivedate=November 27, 2006|df=}} ''[[The Denver Post]]'' initially refused to use the [[Invesco]] label and referred to it as Mile High Stadium for several years before changing its policy and adding Invesco to articles. On August 16, 2011, the Metropolitan Stadium District announced Invesco would immediately transfer the naming rights to [[Englewood, Colorado]]-based [[Sports Authority]] in a 25-year agreement worth $6 million per year. In August of 2016, the Denver Broncos paid $3,601,890 to the Metropolitan Football Stadium District to purchase the naming rights to the stadium.{{cite web|last1=Zellinger|first1=Marhsall|date=May 31, 2016|title=Denver Broncos awarded Mile High Stadium naming rights during Sports Authority bankruptcy case|url=https://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/local-news/denver-broncos-awarded-mile-high-stadium-naming-rights-during-sports-authority-bankruptcy-case/|publisher=''The Denver Channel''|accessdate=27 March 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161101101045/http://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/local-news/denver-broncos-awarded-mile-high-stadium-naming-rights-during-sports-authority-bankruptcy-case|archive-date=1 November 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In 2016, several Colorado legislators attempted to pass a bill in the [[Colorado State Legislature]] that would require the "Mile High" moniker regardless of any naming rights deal, citing the large public contribution to the stadium's construction;{{cite news |last=Bunch |first=Joey |date=August 23, 2016 |title=Bill would forever preserve "Mile High" in Broncos' stadium name |url=http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_29816233/bill-would-forever-preserve-mile-high-broncos-stadium |newspaper=The Denver Post |accessdate=May 5, 2016}} the bill failed to pass out of a Senate Committee in May 2016.{{cite news |last=Bunch |first=Joey |date=May 5, 2016 |title=Senate Republicans kill bill to retain "Mile High" in stadium's name |url=http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_29855852/senate-republicans-kill-bill-retain-mile-high-stadiums |newspaper=The Denver Post |accessdate=May 5, 2016}} ==Usage== The stadium is used primarily for [[American football]] games. It is the home field for Denver's [[National Football League]] team, the [[Denver Broncos]]. The stadium also hosts the city's [[Major League Lacrosse]] team, the [[Denver Outlaws]]. In college football it has hosted the [[Rocky Mountain Showdown|rivalry game]] between the [[Colorado State University]] [[Colorado State Rams football|Rams]] and the [[University of Colorado Boulder]] [[Colorado Buffaloes football|Buffaloes]]. It is also used for the [[Colorado High School Activities Association|CHSAA]] class 4A and 5A Colorado high school football state championship games, and has been used for the CBA Marching Band Finals. In addition, it has been used for the [[Drum Corps International]] (DCI) Championships in 2004 and the annual Drums Along the Rockies competition. It is also used for concerts, music festivals and other events, and was home to the city's [[Major League Soccer]] franchise, the [[Colorado Rapids]], before that team built and moved into [[Dick's Sporting Goods Park]] in suburban [[Commerce City, Colorado|Commerce City]]. On the 23rd June 2018 England defeated New Zealand 36-18 in [[Rugby League]]. ==Location== The construction of the stadium marked the completion of a six-year sporting venue upgrade program in Denver, including the construction of [[Coors Field]] and of [[Pepsi Center]]. As with the other venues, the stadium was constructed to be easily accessible. It sits along [[Interstate 25]] near the [[Colfax Avenue]] and 17th Avenue exits. It is also bordered by Federal Boulevard, a major Denver thoroughfare, on the west side. A dedicated [[Sports Authority Field at Mile High (RTD)|light rail station]] also serves the stadium. The stadium is located in the [[Sun Valley, Denver|Sun Valley neighborhood]]. ==Stadium culture and traditions== A home game tradition (carried over from the original [[Mile High Stadium]]) is the "Incomplete Chant." At Bronco home games, when the opposing team throws an incomplete pass, the stadium announcer will state "Pass thrown by [the opposing quarterback] intended for [the opposing intended receiver] is..." at which time the fans complete the sentence by shouting "IN-COM-PLETE!!".{{cite web |url=http://www.denverbroncos.com/footer/faq.html |title=FAQ |work=Denver Broncos |access-date=2014-07-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819010506/http://www.denverbroncos.com/footer/faq.html |archive-date=2014-08-19 |dead-url=yes |df= }} The stadium has sold out every [[Denver Broncos]]' home game since its inception in {{nfly|2001}}, extending the "sold-out" streak that began during the team's tenure at Mile High Stadium, where every home game had been sold out since {{nfly|1970}} (though due to [[National Football League|NFL]] policy, local TV broadcasts of sold-out games did not start until {{nfly|1973}}). In a tradition carried over from Mile High Stadium, the stadium's public-address announcer will give the final official attendance for the game, including the number of unused tickets; in response, Broncos fans "boo" the no-shows. During the stadium's first years, in another tradition was carried over from Mile High, Broncos fans on one side of the stadium would chant "Go" and fans on the other side would respond "Broncos," back and forth chanting for several minutes. That tradition has since died out. Another long-term tradition is famed rowdiness of fans seated in the "South Stands," although this tradition has diminished significantly as well. Finally, especially in the upper two decks, the fans create their own 'Mile High Thunder' (and warm themselves) by stamping their feet on the stadium's floors. The old Mile High Stadium was built with bare metal, and the 'Thunder' reverberated readily. The new stadium was built with steel floors to preserve this unique acoustic feature.{{cite web |title=The New And Improved Mile High |url=http://www.stadiumjourney.com/stadiums/sports-authority-field-at-mile-high-s66/ |work=Stadium Journey}} On December 21, 2012, the Broncos announced a [[Dollar|$]]30 million renovation project prior to the start of the [[2013 Denver Broncos season|2013]] season, including a new high-definition [[Light emitting diode|LED]] video board on the stadium's south end zone that triples the size of the old video board.{{cite web |author=Klis, Mike |title=Broncos, Stadium District to spend $30 million on Mile High improvements |url=http://www.denverpost.com/broncos/ci_22241443/broncos-stadium-district-spend-30-million-stadium-improvements |newspaper=The Denver Post |date=December 21, 2012 |accessdate=December 21, 2012}} In 2013, it was revealed that a [[Neil Smith (American football)|Neil Smith]] [[Kansas City Chiefs]] jersey was buried somewhere near the 50-yard line by a couple of out-of-state contractors during renovations, despite Smith's play on the Broncos' [[Super Bowl XXXII]] and [[Super Bowl XXXIII|XXXIII]]-winning teams. The curse the contractors hoped to create did not occur as the Broncos won another Super Bowl two years later, [[Super Bowl 50]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefox.com/pages/LandF.html?article=11830461|title=Troy claims a secret lies beneath the 50 yard line... {{!}} The Rick Lewis Show {{!}} 103.5 The Fox|website=103.5 The Fox|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101080916/http://www.thefox.com/pages/LandF.html?article=11830461|archivedate=2014-01-01|df=}} ==Notable events== ===NFL events=== [[File:SAF at Mile High AFC Championship game pom-poms.jpg|thumb|Interior view during the 2013 AFC Championship game]] On September 10, 2001, the stadium hosted its first regular season NFL game, in which the Broncos defeated the [[New York Giants]] 31–20. In a pre-game ceremony, Broncos legends [[John Elway]], [[Steve Atwater]], [[Randy Gradishar]], [[Haven Moses]], Billy Thompson, [[Floyd Little]], Dennis Smith, and [[Karl Mecklenburg]] helped to "Move the Thunder" from the old Mile High Stadium to the new home of the Broncos.{{Citation needed|date=September 2008}} The stadium has hosted several NFL playoff games. It hosted the [[2005–06 NFL playoffs|2005 AFC Divisional playoff game]], in which Denver defeated the [[New England Patriots]] 27–13. The following week, it hosted the [[AFC Championship Game]], which the Broncos lost to the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]], 34–17. On January 8, 2012, the stadium hosted its third NFL playoff game, an [[2011–12 NFL playoffs|AFC Wild Card playoff game]] against the Steelers. The Broncos won in overtime, 29–23. On January 12, 2013, the stadium hosted its fourth NFL playoff game, an [[2012–13 NFL playoffs|AFC Divisional playoff game]] against the [[Baltimore Ravens]]. The Broncos lost to the Ravens [[Mile High Miracle|38–35 in double overtime]].{{Citation needed|date=November 2013}} On October 29, 2007, a record crowd of 77,160 watched the Broncos lose to the [[Green Bay Packers]] 19–13 on [[Monday Night Football]] on the first play from scrimmage in overtime.{{Citation needed|date=November 2013}} On November 26, 2009, it hosted its first [[NFL on Thanksgiving Day|Thanksgiving game]], when the Broncos took on the Giants. The game was televised on [[NFL Network]], which the Broncos won by a final score of 26–6.{{Citation needed|date=November 2013}} On January 19, 2014, the Broncos defeated the Patriots in the AFC Championship Game, 26–16 in front of 77,110 fans in attendance, advancing to their first [[Super Bowl XLVIII|Super Bowl]] since they began play in the new stadium. On January 17, 2016, the Broncos defeated the Steelers in the AFC Divisional playoffs, 23–16 in front of 77,100, advancing to the [[AFC Championship Game]] for the 10th time in franchise history. On January 24, 2016, the Broncos defeated the Patriots in the AFC Championship Game, 20–18 in front of 77,100, advancing to [[Super Bowl 50]], which they won two weeks later. ===Soccer=== On July 26, 2014, Sports Authority Field at Mile High hosted a soccer match between [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] and [[A.S. Roma]] which was part of the [[2014 International Champions Cup]] and Manchester United won the match 3-2.It included a 60 yard goal by Miralem Pjanic of AS Roma, adding to mile high's reputation as a good place to kick long field goals. [http://internationalchampionscup.com/news/?article_id=104 United Survive late Roma Surge to gain first ICC Victory] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140728133057/http://internationalchampionscup.com/news/?article_id=104 |date=2014-07-28 }} ICC.com July 26, 2014 Retrieved July 27, 2014 {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:95%;" style="text-align:center" |- !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Denver Broncos|border=2}};"|Date !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Denver Broncos|border=2}};"|Winning Team !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Denver Broncos|border=2}};"|Result !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Denver Broncos|border=2}};"|Losing Team !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Denver Broncos|border=2}};"|Tournament !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Denver Broncos|border=2}};"|Spectators |- |style="text-align:center;|July 26, 2014||'''{{flagicon|ENG}} [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]'''||style="text-align:center;|3-2|| {{flagicon|ITA}} [[A.S. The first football game held was the [[Rocky Mountain Showdown]], when the [[2001 Colorado Buffaloes football team|University of Colorado Buffaloes]] defeated the [[Colorado State Rams football|Colorado State University Rams]] 41–14. On July 2, 2005, it hosted the 2005 [[Major League Lacrosse All-Star Game]]. In 2006, [[Major League Lacrosse]] placed the expansion [[Denver Outlaws|Outlaws]] in Denver. In August 2004, it hosted the [[Drum Corps International]] (DCI) World Championships, and every July hosts [[Drums Along the Rockies]], which is a major competition in the annual DCI summer tour. {{cite web |url=http://www.dci.org/about/champions|title=Drum Corps International Past Champions and Locations}}{{Cite news|url=http://ascendperformingarts.org/events/datr/|title=Drums Along The Rockies|date=2014-08-13|work=Ascend Performing Arts|access-date=2017-10-30|language=en-US}} On August 28, 2008, Democratic presidential nominee [[Barack Obama]] accepted the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]'s nomination for [[President of the United States]] here, moving the [[2008 Democratic National Convention]] from [[Pepsi Center]]. Approximately 84,000 people attended Obama's speech, exceeding the normal capacity of the stadium due to the placement of audience on the field.{{cite news |title=Obama Accepts Democrat Nomination|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7586375.stm|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|date=August 29, 2008|accessdate=August 29, 2008}}{{cite web |url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5ifKB19ybvy7awq-_PZgkHUerrDBgD92RLNVG1|title=Obama Greeted By Screaming Crowd at Stadium|publisher=[[Associated Press]]|date=August 28, 2008|accessdate=August 29, 2008}}{{dead link|date=November 2012|bot=Legobot}}{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-na-tvcritic29-2008aug29,0,3593116.story|title=Barack Obama, Al Gore Raise the Roof at Invesco Field|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|first=Robert|last=Lloyd|date=August 29, 2008|accessdate=August 29, 2008}}{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/news/politics/2008/articles/2008/08/29/some_saw_spectacular_others_just_spectacle/|title=Some Saw Spectacular, Others Just Spectacle |newspaper= [[The Boston Globe]] |first=Lisa|last=Wangsness |date=August 29, 2008|accessdate=August 29, 2008}} ==Denver Broncos Ring of Fame== The Denver Broncos Ring of Fame was created in 1984 by team owner Pat Bowlen to honor former players and administrators who played significant roles in the franchise's history. The names and years of service (and in most cases, jersey numbers) of the men inducted into the ring are displayed on the Level 5 facade of the stadium. There is no specific number of new members that may be chosen for induction in any given year; in many years, no new members were inducted. {| class="wikitable" |- | style="background:#ff9; width:3em;"| |Inducted or Enshrined in the [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]] {{cite web|url=http://www.profootballhof.com/hof/years.aspx|title=Years - Hall of Famers - Pro Football Hall of Fame Official Site|website=www.profootballhof.com}} |- |} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! 2011–present || 1999 |- | '''77''' || [[Karl Mecklenburg]] || LB || 1983–95 || 2001 |- | '''49''' || [[Dennis Smith (American football)|Dennis Smith]] || S || 1981–94 || 2001 |- | '''65''' || style="background:#ff9"|[[Gary Zimmerman]] || [[Offensive tackle|OT]] || 1993–97 || 2003 |- | '''27''' || [[Steve Atwater]] || S || 1989–98 || 2005 |- | '''30''' || style="background:#ff9"|[[Terrell Davis]] || RB || 1995–2001 || 2007 |- | '''84''' || style="background:#ff9"|[[Shannon Sharpe]] || TE || 1990–99, 2002–03 || 2009 |- | '''80''' || [[Rod Smith (wide receiver)|Rod Smith]] || WR || 1994–2006 || 2012 |- | '''66''' || [[Tom Nalen]] || [[Center (American and Canadian football)|C]] || 1994–2007 || 2013 |- | '''21''' || [[Gene Mingo]] || [[Running back|RB]], [[Placekicker|K]], [[Return specialist|RS]] || 1960–64 || 2014 |- | – || [[Dan Reeves]] || [[List of Denver Broncos head coaches|Head coach]] || 1981–92 || 2014 |- | '''80''' || [[Rick Upchurch]] || [[Wide receiver|WR]], [[Return specialist|RS]] || 1975–83 || 2014 |- | – || [[Pat Bowlen]] || Owner || 1984–present || 2015 |- | '''1''' || [[Jason Elam]] || [[Placekicker|PK]] || 1993–2007 || 2016 |- | '''73''' || [[Simon Fletcher (American football)|Simon Fletcher]] || LB/DE || 1985–95 || 2016 |- | '''47''' || [[John Lynch (American football)|John Lynch]] || S || 2004–07 || 2016 |- | — || [[Red Miller]] || [[List of Denver Broncos head coaches|Head coach]] || 1977–80 || 2017 |} While the Ring of Fame was carried over from the old stadium to the new, the names were re-ordered to separate the inductees who served the team during the pre-[[Pat Bowlen]] (the team's current owner and founder of the Ring) era from those who served during Bowlen's ownership. One of the most noticeable changes was the move of [[John Elway]]'s name to the center of the ring, located directly between the goalposts of the north end zone.{{cite news |url=http://www.denver-rmn.com/invesco/bowlen.shtml|title=Kickoff: Birth of a Stadium|first=Kyle|last=Ringo|accessdate=November 30, 2006|newspaper=[[Rocky Mountain News]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060722000424/http://www.denver-rmn.com/invesco/bowlen.shtml |archivedate=July 22, 2006}} ==Colorado Sports Hall of Fame Museum== The [[Colorado Sports Hall of Fame]] Museum opened in August 2001. {{use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Unreferenced|date=October 2008}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Butcher's Arms Ground | nickname = "The Slaughterhouse"
"Abattoir" | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = Butcher's Arms Ground - October 2007.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = The main stand at Butcher's Arms Ground | fullname = | former_names = | location = Market Street, [[Droylsden]], M43 7AW | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = 1892 | opened = | renovated = 1952 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = [[Grass]] | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 3,000 (500 seated) | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = {{infobox stadium/tenantlist | tenant_clubs = [[Droylsden F.C.]]
Droylsden United
[[Droylsden F.C.]] | tenant_years = 1892-1945
1945-1952
1952-present}} }} '''Butcher's Arms Ground''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Droylsden]], [[Tameside]], [[Greater Manchester]], [[England]]. It is currently used mostly for [[Association football|football]] matches and is the home ground of [[Droylsden F.C.]]. The stadium has a capacity of 3,000 people both seated and standing and is nicknamed "The Slaughterhouse" or "Abattoir" by fans. The ''Butchers'' reference is celebrated at a designated home game once a year, when the stadium floor is sprinkled with saw dust and fans are invited to wear white overalls and hairnets. During Droylsden's recent F.A. Cup tie against [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]], broadcast live on ESPN, two fans invaded the pitch at the end of the match dressed as butchers. It has partial or full cover on three sides of the pitch, terracing on four sides and seating along the centre of one side, plus a [[public house]]. The ground is named after the Butcher's Arms public house, whose landlord in 1892 instigated the formation of Droylsden FC to play on land behind the pub, which became the ground. After the [[Second World War]] the lease of the Butchers Arms was sold to Belle Vue F.C., who renamed themselves Droylsden United. And that club took over playing at the ground, forcing Drolysden to move to the nearby [[Moorside, Oldham|Moorside]] Trotting Stadium. However, the town wasn't big enough for two clubs, especially with bad feeling between them, and after the local council bought the ground, a merger was negotiated and Drolysden returned to the Butcher's Arms ground in 1952, after it had been renovated and the pitch had been rotated to its present position, finally eradicating a long-standing drainage problem. The record attendance is 4,250 for an [[FA Cup]] first round match between Droylsden and [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]] in 1976. {{coord|53|28|54.69|N|2|08|41.64|W|region:GB_type:landmark|display=title}} {{Football in Greater Manchester}} [[Category:Football venues in England]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Tameside]] [[Category:Sport in Tameside]] [[Category:Sports venues in Greater Manchester]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1892]] [[Category:Droylsden]] {{England-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox sport governing body |name = Canadian Association for Stock Car Auto Racing |abbrev = CASCAR |logo = Cascarlogo.jpg |logosize = |sport = [[Stock car racing]] |category = [[Auto racing]] |image = |caption = |jurisdiction = {{flagicon|Canada}} [[Canada]] |founded = {{Start date|1981}} |aff = |affdate = |region = |regionyear = |headquarters = [[Delaware, Ontario]] |president = [[Anthony Novotny]] |chairman = |chairperson = |chair = |chiefexec = |secretary = |key staff = |operating income = |sponsor = [[General Tire]]
[[Budweiser (Anheuser-Busch)|Budweiser]]
[[Castrol]] |year closed = 2006 |replaced = |prevfounded = |url = |countryflag = Canada |countryflag2 = |countryflag3 = }} The '''Canadian Association for Stock Car Auto Racing''' ('''CASCAR''') was the governing body for amateur and professional [[Stock car racing|stock car]] racing in [[Canada]]. ==History== Established in 1981 by President Anthony Novotny, CASCAR boasted the highest level of stock car racing in Canada and sanctioned Canada's only national stock car racing series, the [[CASCAR Super Series]]. On November 16, 2004, CASCAR announced it had entered a multi-year operational and marketing agreement with [[NASCAR]],{{cite web|url=http://www.motorsport.com/nascar/news/nascar-enters-alliance-with-cascar/|title=CASCAR enters agreement with NASCAR|publisher=motorsport.com|accessdate=February 16, 2015}} after NASCAR had formed [[NASCAR Canada]] earlier in the year. This also opened the way for NASCAR's purchase of CASCAR.[https://web.archive.org/web/20060214230927/http://www.autonet.ca/Motorsports/story.cfm?story=/Motorsports/NASCAR/2005/11/26/1325184-sun.html] Jim Cressman, [[London Free Press]] "NASCAR close to buying CASCAR", accessed January 1, 2007 On September 12, 2006, NASCAR completed its purchase of CASCAR and announced the [[NASCAR Canadian Tire Series]], a series of 10–12 races from May–October 2007.[https://www.tsn.ca/auto_racing/news_story/?ID=177222&hubname= TSN.ca staff, "NASCAR launches series in Canada" September 12, 2006, Retrieved January 1, 2007] On December 7, 2015, it was announced that Pinty's Delicious Foods Inc. was the new sponsor of the series after Canadian Tire announced on February 17, 2015 that they were not renewing their sponsorship after the 2015 season.{{cite news|last=Pappone|first=Jeff|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-drive/news/motorsports/canadian-tire-looking-to-end-partnership-with-canadian-nascar-series/article23023894/|title=Canadian Tire ending partnership with Canadian NASCAR series|newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=February 17, 2015|accessdate=February 18, 2015}}{{cite web|url = http://hometracks.nascar.com/ncats/story/pintys-sponsor-canadian-series_12072015|title = Pinty's To Sponsor Canadian Series|date = December 7, 2015|accessdate = December 7, 2015|publisher = NASCAR Media Group|website = NASCAR.com|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151211113543/http://hometracks.nascar.com/ncats/story/pintys-sponsor-canadian-series_12072015|archivedate = December 11, 2015|df = }} ==Automobiles== Unlike NASCAR, which mandates the use of steel-bodied shells, CASCAR-approved cars consisted of fiberglass bodyshells covering custom-made tube-frame racing chassis. However, as in NASCAR, CASCAR cars' engines were [[Carburetor|normally aspirated]], pushrod [[V8 engine|V8]] units producing approximately {{convert|500|hp}}. ==Race courses== CASCAR events were held on [[Short track motor racing|short track]] ovals, permanent road courses, temporary road courses and street courses. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.insidetracknews.com CASCAR's official publication website] *[http://www.nascar.com/2006/news/headlines/official/09/13/nascar.cascar.purchase/index.html NASCAR press release, September 13, 2006: NASCAR launches new race series in Canada] {{DEFAULTSORT:Cascar}} [[Category:Motorsport in Canada]] [[Category:Stock car racing]] [[Category:CASCAR| ]] [[Category:Auto racing organizations]] {{motorsport-stub}} {{Canada-sport-stub}}

revision.text: {{Infobox volleyball club | club name = Club Africain Volleyball | short name = ''CA'', ''Al Ifriqi'' | nickname = ''El Ghalia'', ''El hamra'' | image = | fullname = Club Africain | founded = [[1943 in sports|1943]] | dissolved = [[2001 in sports|2001]] | ground = Salle Chérif-Bellamine, [[Tunis]] | capacity = 1,500 | chairman = | captain = | league = [[Tunisian Men's Volleyball League|Tunisian Volleyball League]] | season = | position = | website = http://www.clubafricain.com/ | pattern_la1=_white_hoops|pattern_b1=_redhoops|pattern_ra1=_white_hoops | leftarm1=ED2024|body1=ffffff|rightarm1=ED2024|shorts1=ED2024 | pattern_la2=_white_hoops|pattern_b2=_redhoops|pattern_ra2=_white_hoops | leftarm2=ED2024|body2=ffffff|rightarm2=ED2024|shorts2=FFFFFF }} The '''Club Africain Men's Volleyball Club''' ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]: '''النادي الافريقي للكرة الطائرة''', [[English language|English]]: ''' African Club''' or '''CA''') was a [[volleyball]] team based in the Tunisian capital [[Tunis]] which was part of the omnisport [[Club Africain]]. Founded in [[1943 in sports|1943]], it competed in the [[Tunisian Men's Volleyball League]] where it enjoyed some success, especially in the 1980s and 1990s. Due to economic issues, the team was dissolved in [[2001 in sports|2001]]. ==Honours== ===National titles=== * '''[[Tunisian Men's Volleyball League|Tunisian Volleyball League]]''' 7 : ::[[File:Simple gold cup.svg|16px]] '''Champions''' : 1980–81, 1982–83, 1988–89, 1989–90, 1990–91, 1991–92, 1993–94 ::[[File:Simple silver cup.svg|16px]] ''Vice Champion'' : 1981–82, 1983–84, 1986–87, 1992–93, 1995–96, * '''[[Tunisian Volleyball Cup]]''' 5 : ::[[File:Simple gold cup.svg|16px]] '''Champions''' : 1982–83, 1983–84, 1989–90, 1990–91, 1991–92 ::[[File:Simple silver cup.svg|16px]] ''Runners Up'' : 1977–78, 1981–82 ===International titles=== * '''[[African Clubs Championship (volleyball)|African Champions Cup]]''' 3 : ::[[File:Gold medal africa.svg|16px]] '''Champions''' : 1991, 1992, 1993 * '''[[African Volleyball Cup Winners' Cup|African Cup Winners' Cup]]''' 1 : ::[[File:Gold medal africa.svg|16px]] '''Champions''' : 1992 ::[[File:Silver medal africa.svg|16px]] ''Runners Up'' : 1991 ::[[File:Bronze medal africa.svg|16px]] ''Bronze medal'' : 1993 * '''[[FIVB Volleyball Men's Club World Championship|FIVB Club World Championship]] :: Best Performance '''7th Place''' : [[1991 FIVB Volleyball Men's Club World Championship|1991]], [[1992 FIVB Volleyball Men's Club World Championship|1992]] ===Regional Titles=== * '''[[Arab Clubs Championship (volleyball)|Arab Clubs Championship]]''' 2 : ::[[File:Simple gold cup.svg|16px]] '''Champions''' : 1992, 1994 ::[[File:Simple silver cup.svg|16px]] ''Runners Up'' : 1995 ==Last Squad 2001== {| class="toccolours" style="border: #ED2024 solid 1px; background: #FFFFFF; font-size: 95%" |- ! colspan="5" style="background-color:#FFFFFF;" | {{Font color|#ED2024|'''Club Africain Volleyball roster'''}} |- | style="fnto-size: 95%;" valign="top" | '''Players List''' *  0? revision.comment: /* top */ Now a WNYC Studios co-prod
revision.text:
{{Infobox podcast | title = ''Dear Hank & John'' | image = Dear_Hank_And_John_Pocast_Cover_Art.jpg | caption = Dear Hank & John Podcast Cover Art | host = [[Hank Green]] & [[John Green (author)|John Green]] | genre = {{Unbulleted list | Comedy }} | updates = Weekly | language = English | production = Nicholas Jenkins | theme_music_composer = [[Gunnarolla]] | audio format = Podcast (via streaming or downloadable MP3) | num_seasons = | num_episodes = 158 | began = June 7, 2015 | ended = | provider = | website = [https://soundcloud.com/dearhankandjohn 'Dear Hank & John']|thumb|center| | cited_for = | cited_as = }} '''''Dear Hank & John''''' is a [[podcast]] hosted by the [[Green brothers]]: musician and [[YouTube]] entrepreneur [[Hank Green]] and [[Young adult fiction|young-adult]] novelist and [[film producer]], [[John Green (author)|John Green]]. The podcast is produced and edited by Nicholas Jenkins with additional help from [[Rosianna Halse Rojas]]. First released in June 2015, Hank and John Green answer questions e-mailed by listeners, give "dubious" advice and talk about the weekly news for the planet [[Mars]] and the 3rd tier [[Football in England|English football]] club [[AFC Wimbledon]]. Episodes are typically around 45 minutes in length.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/dear-hank-john/id1002937870?mt=2|title=Dear Hank & John by Hank Green and John Green on iTunes|website=iTunes|access-date=2016-04-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://boingboing.net/2015/06/19/vlogbrothers-launch-their-own.html|title=Vlogbrothers launch their own podcast|date=2015-06-19|website=Boing Boing|access-date=2016-05-26}}</ref> Upon the podcast's debut, it reached the number 4 position on the [[United States|US]] [[iTunes]] performance chart and hit a peak position of number 2 two days later. ''Dear Hank & John'' has also been charted on iTunes in the [[United Kingdom]], [[Germany]], [[France]], [[Italy]], [[Canada]], [[Spain]], [[Australia]] and [[Brazil]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.itunescharts.net/us/artists/podcast/dear-hank-john/podcasts/dear-hank-john/|title=iTunesCharts.net: 'Dear Hank & John' by Dear Hank & John (American Podcasts iTunes Chart)|website=www.itunescharts.net|access-date=2016-04-22}}</ref> The podcast is primarily funded through the crowdfunding website [[Patreon]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.patreon.com/dearhankandjohn?ty=h|title=Dear Hank and John is creating Dubious Advice {{!}} Patreon|website=Patreon|access-date=2016-04-22}}</ref> though the majority of the pledges go towards the video production budget of [[Complexly]]. Since November 2018, the podcast is a co-production of Complexly and [[WNYC Studios]].
The podcast follows a general format which starts with an opening section. It usually changes every two or three months. As of now (ep. 148), John tries to give good news and Hank tells a “dad joke”. The main portion of the show then has the brothers offering comedic advice to questions received from listeners. Usually, at some point in the question segment, the brothers 'plug' various 'sponsors' of the show in a humorous manner that references topics from that week. The show then moves to the news segment, with Hank delivering the news about [[Mars]] and John the news about the [[AFC Wimbledon]] football club. Finally, the brothers discuss 'what they learned today', before reading the credits at the show's close.<ref>{{Citation|last=Dear Hank and John|title=Dear Hank and John 001 - The Debut: Do You Pee on Your Own Head?|date=2016-01-20|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iYcyYh-sTj0|accessdate=2016-04-22}}</ref> The brothers' schedule has sometimes led them to miss several episodes (notably for John during the summer of 2015 due to the ''[[Paper Towns (film)|Paper Towns]]'' publicity tour, and for Hank in late 2016 for his paternity leave); various friends of the brothers have filled in for each missing host on those occasions.
In March 2017, a 'bonus' supplemental podcast, titled ''This Week in Ryans'', started to become available for those who support the podcast on [[Patreon]] at the $5/month level or higher. In each episode, a person or thing named Ryan is selected to be discussed and analyzed by the hosts in a short segment.
An exclusive Dear Hank & John episode has been made as a perk for the annual [[Project for Awesome]] fundraising campaign<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hypable.com/project-for-awesome-2015/|title=The Project for Awesome 2015 kicks off today|date=2015-12-11|website=Hypable|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.indystar.com/story/entertainment/arts/2015/12/03/john-green-dftba-p4a-nerdfighters-tfios-podcast-indianapolis/76721118/|title=Annual 'Awesome' fundraiser on deck for John Green|website=Indianapolis Star|access-date=2016-05-26}}</ref> each year since 2015.
== Live Performances ==
On John's book tour for ''[[Turtles All the Way Down (novel)|Turtles All the Way Down]]'' (October 10 - November 2, 2017) the Green brothers put on about a two hour long performance filled with monologues, silly songs, and a live version of Dear Hank & John.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.turtlesallthewaydownbook.com/#tour|title=Turtles All The Way Down Tour|last=|first=|date=|website=www.turtlesallthewaydownbook.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> This live production of their podcast included taking real questions from real Nerdfighters who were in attendance in the audience at that particular stop of the tour. Segments that were recorded across the tour were later edited into a single podcast, and released as its 114th episode.
== Platforms ==
Dear Hank and John is available to listeners on a multitude of platforms. Most commonly streamed on [[iTunes]]<ref name=":0" /> the podcast also has thousands of "views" on the Dear Hank and John [[YouTube]] page<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCldoL0vMV7hkUPIauUY4IjA|title=Dear Hank and John Youtube Channel|last=|first=|date=|website=www.YouTube.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> where they upload episodes several days after the initial release on iTunes. The podcast has also been released on audio websites like [[SoundCloud]], PodBay.fm, and many other podcast related websites.
== List of Episodes<ref name=":0" /> == {| class="wikitable" !Episode No. !Original Release Date !Episode Title !Notes |- |1 |7 Jun 2015 |The Debut: Do You Pee on Your Own Head? | |- |2 |16 Jun 2015 |It's a Humour Podcast! | |- |3 |23 Jun 2015 |Pain Demands to be Felt. | |- |4 |30 Jun 2015 |What's in a Name? | |- |5 |7 Jul 2015 |Should I Lie to Get a Job?* |Guest: [[Maureen Johnson]] |- |6 |15 Jul 2015 |Would You Eat a Moon Sandwich?* |Guest: [[Emma Blackery]] |- |7 |22 Jul 2015 |What to do about Stomach Farts?* |Guests: [[Charlie McDonnell]] and Jimmy Hill |- |8 |29 Jul 2015 |Dear Hank and Grace!* |Guest: [[Grace Helbig]] |- |9 |5 Aug 2015 |Dear Hank and Felicia* |Guest: [[Felicia Day]] |- |10 |12 Aug 2015 |When Your Friend Likes Ayn Rand... | |- |11 |18 Aug 2015 |How do you "Make Something of Yourself"? | |- |12 |25 Aug 2015 |Tree Climbing Strategies | |- |13 |1 Sep 2015 |John and Hank and Wheezy Waiter! |Guest: [[Craig Benzine]] |- |14 |9 Sep 2015 |Jurassic Mars | |- |15 |15 Sep 2015 |Get That in Your Mouth! | |- |16 |22 Sep 2015 |Handling Awful Roomates(sic) | |- |17 |29 Sep 2015 |Meeting Taylor Swift('s parents) | |- |18 |7 Oct 2015 |Coming to Terms with your Nerdiness | |- |19 |12 Oct 2015 |Should I Abandon My Stuffed Animal? revision.text:
The '''Foothills Major Baseball Association (FMBA)''' is a '''men's [[baseball]] league''' located in [[Calgary, Alberta]], [[Canada]]. It plays games out of Deerfoot Stadium which is located off of Deerfoot Trail & 32nd Ave. NE. There are currently 11 teams in the league, whom each play a 22-game schedule prior to playoffs. It runs from early May until the end of August.
In 2017, the Calgary Cardinals won the FMBA Championship defeating the Calgary Dukes in the final, 2 games to 1.
==Member Teams==
The league currently plays a balanced 22 game schedule. *[[Calgary Cardinals FMBA|Calgary Cardinals]] *[[Calgary Diamondbacks]] *[[Calgary Dukes]] *Airdrie Brewers *[http://www.ballcharts.com/team/?team=calgarygiants&pg=index Calgary Giants] *[[Calgary Guns]] *[http://www.longhorns.ca Calgary Longhorns] *[[Calgary Mets|Calgary Twins]] *[[Calgary White Sox]] *[[Calgary Wolfpack]] *Calgary Canadians
==League History==
The league was started in 1979, when Doc Cody and Ron McCartney petitioned the City for a more permanent baseball facility for amateur players over the age of 18. At that time, the three original teams in the league: the Cardinals, Caseys & Odeons played out of Optimist Park before it was decided they needed to do something about the need for more playing space.
In true Calgary form, volunteers from the community stepped forward and offered to construct a major league size park on City land. The main sponsor and benefactor was Jim Wilfley, with able assistance from other sports enthusiasts such as Hank Bassen, Gem-Sod, [[Alberta Treasury Branch]], [[Coca-Cola]], Conmac and others. The park was built on traditional ball park lines with wooden fences, stands and a press box. The project was started in the Fall of 1982 and finished in August 1984. The entire facility was built with donated labor and funding. The league opened for play, debt free, thanks to the dedicated generosity of its sponsors.
The first president was Ron McCartney. Glen Hansen took over in 1982. Many people over the years have contributed their volunteer efforts to keep the league going.
In 1991, the facility was partially destroyed by a fire set by vandals. The reconstruction work that followed changed the appearance of the park radically as all the wooden fences and structures were removed in favor of vandal-proof facilities. The present facility was reconstructed under the presidency of Ray Brisson with funds from the fire insurance and a generous grant from the Saddledome Foundation.
==Past Champions==
*2017: Calgary Cardinals *2016: Calgary Diamondbacks *2015: Calgary Longhorns *2014: Calgary Wolfpack *2013: Calgary Longhorns *2012: Calgary Guns *2011: Calgary Wolfpack *2010: Calgary Gamecocks *2009: Calgary Gamecocks *2008: Calgary Longhorns *2007: Calgary Longhorns *2006: Calgary Longhorns *2005: Calgary Dust Devils *2004: Calgary Longhorns *2003: Calgary Cardinals
==External links== *[http://www.fmba.ca FMBA Website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090915181941/http://www.calgarycardinals.com/ Calgary Cardinals website] *[http://www.longhorns.ca Calgary Longhorns website] *[http://www.ballcharts.com/team/?team=calgarygiants&pg=index Calgary Giants website]
